There are 40 days left in 2016. UNHCR reports (http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php) that as of this forecast, about 344,600 refugees have arrived in 2016. If traffic were uniformly distributed across the year, then we should expect a total around 380,000 refugees this year. As it happens, I believe the total number is actually going to be closer to around 360,000. The 650,000 needed to make this true represents a tripling of the highest-traffic month of the crisis (221,000 in October 2015). This probability is vastly closer to 0 than to 1, but nothing is impossible and GJO requires integer forecasts :(

The International Organization for Migration (IOM) has reported that 269,244 migrants and refugees have entered Europe by sea in 2016 through 21 August, an increase of 3,218 since 17 August. The number of arrivals so far in 2016 is slightly lower than the number recorded through the first eight months of 2015, when a total of 354,618 migrants and refugees were recorded crossing the Mediterranean, the majority of them coming from Turkey to Greece. Arrivals in Greece total 162,599 in 2016 through 21 August, down from 234,357 in the first eight months of 2015. Arrivals in Italy have also decreased, albeit at a lower rate. A total of 104,141 migrants and refugees arrived in Italy across the Mediterranean this year so far, compared with 116,147 in 2015 through 31 August.

August is a critical month.  -Last year there were ~220K migrants and refugees by the end of July and ~350K by the end of August, and the trend was towards sharply increasing numbers. 
-This year there were ~250K migrants and refugees by the end of July, but the trend is towards a flat 25K a month. The political situation also appears to favor smaller numbers. If by the end of August we're not at least on par with last year, I think it will be very very hard for this question to resolve with a yes (short of a political and humanitarian catastrophe).

Vox: "Turkey’s recent failed coup may lead to the worsening of Europe’s migration crisis. That’s because it could lead to the dissolution of a recent pact between Brussels and Ankara over the plight of refugees arriving on the European Union’s shores. Even before the events of last weekend, the fate of the agreement was uncertain amid quarrels between the parties. Now its future is even more in doubt"[1].  In short, increased uncertainty in Turkey means increased uncertainty about whether the arrangement preventing (more or less) a very large inflow to Europe of refugees and migrants will hold up. That said, (a) President Erdoğan doesn't appear to have much to gain from abrogating his arrangement with the EU, (b) has a lot of other business to attend to in trying to consolidate his power after the failed coup, (c) is more likely to want to use the arrangement for leverage with his western partners.  But what if Pres. Erdoğan just walked away from the deal today? In order to get to 1 million refugees and migrants by the end of December, we'd need to see about 760,000 over the next 5 months. That's an average of 152,000 per month. And what, you ask, was the average rate of inflow from the last 5 months of 2015? Roughly 155,00[2]. In 2015 just over 1 million arrived in Europe by sea. Comparison of 2016 to 2015 seems a reasonable way to answer the question therefore. The start of 2016 appeared to demonstrate a much higher trend of sea arrival, whilst the most recent data from April 2016 supports a decrease in arrivals. The breakdown of the problem needs to be examined from multiple angles, this is easiest to do by examining the journey itself: driving pressure (factors that would produce the desire to migrate), perceived and actual difficulties of the journey itself and perceived and actual benefits obtainable at the journey's conclusion.  Driving pressures:
Both North Africa and the Middle East contribute to the sea-bound migrating population, which is itself a reflection of the total migrating population. Looking at the population breakdown (UNHCR), it is largely Syrian/Afghan/Iraqi. With the greatest numbers from coming from these regions, the driving forces in these areas are the most relevant in answering the question. Syria is currently undergoing peace talks, and although heavily flawed and perpetually on the verge of collapse, the fact that they are occurring might reduce current migration. If they were to collapse, then it is likely that there will be an increase in migration again. In Afghanistan, the recent start of the summer Taliban offensive has started with a highly aggressive action in Kabul, whilst this may itself be a singular event, it may also represent the start of a more aggressive period which would potentially lead to higher migration. Similarly in Iraq, high tensions between Shia and Shi'ite groups which have precipitated recent direct actions against parliament may compound the ongoing instability from the actions of ISIL. Overall, these factors suggest that the main contributory source migration countries will continue to have strong driving pressures for migration and that these may be higher this year than last year. Overall summary: likely similar or greater driving pressures to 2015 ( estimate +10-+15%). journey troubles:
The journey is expensive, dangerous and contains an unpredictable criminal element. In particular, the sea journey must include a criminal element to make the crossing and therefore this probably represents a negative factor on migration due to the high initial costs and limited supply. However, access is now restricted across the EU land border countries, and plans are afoot to increase the difficulty of access to Turkey which, though not a part of Europe itself, plays a pivotal role in the journey. This may decrease the migration initially as refugees are forced to re-route but may also lead to more sea crossings across either the Black sea or longer routes across the Mediterranean. The sea crossing is also affected by patrolling naval/coast guard actions and, to a lesser extent, the various NGO groups who are also involved, however these factors are likely to remain fairly static this year as resources are already stretched. Unpredictable effects, such as the weather, will also play a role in effects month-to-month but may even out if viewed across the whole year, and in any case, are difficult to forecast. The perceived difficulties of making the journey may also affect the numbers attempting the journey, indeed many of the counter migratory strategies seem to hinge on this, however commentaries have made much on the use of social media/mobile communications to stay updated on difficult travel by refugees and it is likely that the perceived difficulties will fluctuate rapidly as the various other effects on the journey play out. Again, at this time, the effect of this, and indeed attempting to quantify the effect of this "perceived difficulty" aspect on migration strategy is difficult to interpret, though it will be unlikely to affect total short term travel numbers greatly. Summary: slight decrease (estimate 0 - -5%). Reward at the journey's conclusion.
Europe has received a high number of refugees across the past few years. Public sentiment across Europe is currently equivocal in supporting their acceptance and is likely to wane further as incidents occur between refugees and locals and resources are stretched to and beyond breaking points in countries with already shaky economies. This will lead to political moves to both spread the refugee load (to less desirable end locations), make access harder and to decrease the benefits to the migrant. Again, the effects of this across the year on migration by sea will depend on the "perception of benefit" by potential refugees in their home locations. There may therefore be a long term decrease in attractiveness of migration. However, in the short term this might be a smaller effect. Summary: short term small effect, potentially long term decrease (estimate 0 - -5%). Summary: Clearly there are a huge number of factors involved in the question. Many cannot be estimated with any sense of accuracy e.g. the changes that demand has on the supply of sea transport given the criminal aspect of the market or the impact of fast intra-migrant communications on journey decision planning. The 55% figure I gave represents an attempt to summate the known effects compared to last year (where a figure of just over a million was reached). In phrasing the question like that, it becomes one where comparison of these factors is made with last year rather than a nebulous abstraction. Of the obvious factors, I would currently consider "driving forces" in the relevant countries as having probably the greatest effect of migration totals and therefore the numbers attempting a sea crossing. As these in turn are dependent on geopolitical factors that are currently unfavourable, there will likely be similar or slightly more refugees compared to last year. Whilst changes to the journey and the attractiveness of the end location also affect the overall numbers, by my analysis these effects are likely to remain roughly similar to last year, despite changes in both areas that may lead to mid to long term decreases in migration attempts, however it will be very interesting to review these effects as the year unfolds.

At this point, the question is asking whether or not anything close to the problems of 2015 in Syria will crop up again somewhere else. 2015 is the only year in the last decade that crested the 1 million mark, and even then was only over by 15k. The next highest was 2014 with 216k, though 2016 will almost certainly break into second as it currently stands at 180k. A simple projection from the fact that we are at about 31% of the way through the year yields 580k, well under the million mark. Furthermore, the monthly trend has clearly been going downward after its peak in October 2015 (http://i.imgur.com/oKBHtz3.png), whereas the number had been increasing at this point last year. Barring an event like Syria last year, the number of refugees will not exceed 1 million. I'd put the likelihood of such an event at under 20%, but even with such an event, we saw how close it was. Maybe a 50% chance it's over if something similar happens in 2016. All said, I'm going with 10% of a Syria 2015-like event in 2016, and 50% chance of breaking 1 million with said event, for a total of 5%.

There's strong evidence that the EU's (ham-fisted and ill considered) attempts to reduce the inflow of migrants and refugees is working. During the period of April 1-15, less than 8,000 migrants and refugees have arrived on Europe's shores. That's about half of what we saw last year during this same period[1]. As @Anneinak, @dkc, and @Milosz (as well as others) have pointed out, migrants and refugees are already seeking out other routes - especially Libya-Italy - in place of Turkey-Greece. But it is in no way clear that these alternative routes will support that average of 100,000 migrants and refugees/month for the rest of the year that would be necessary to reach 1,000,000 sea-borne arrivals that is the subject of this question. At the moment, the "human smuggling infrastructure" (I'm sorry, but I can't recall from whom I've borrowed that phrase) does not appear to be in place to move so many people. That might change in the long-run, but I have some doubts about it doing so before 2016 ends. All that said, caution is warranted. Most of the inflow of migrants and refugees to Europe occurs during the last 4 months of the year. So there's a very real possibility of reaching a million, but right now I don't think that possibility can be much more than 2-to-1 against. EDIT: Let me add a little perspective. Almost four months into 2016, less than 25,000 migrants and refugees have arrived on Italian shores (mostly Sicilian shores, to be precise). So (assuming that seaborne arrivals via the Turkey-Greece route fall to about 10% of 2015 numbers), you'd have to see about a twenty-fold increase of migrants and refugees coming from North Africa to get close to 1,000,000 total. I doubt that that kind of increase is likely during the next 8 months. Why? Well, here's the a priori case: Smuggling isn't easy. Generally, it's a reprehensible line of work, but clandestinely getting people across the Mediterranean Sea from North Africa to Sicily, landing these folks on the coast, and then skedaddling it back home to do it all again involves a lot of skill. It's not as if fishmongers and waiters are going to enter the smuggling market. Nor is it likely that smugglers could hire qualified people to do this work on short notice.  To repeat, that's just the a priori case. Maybe there are facts on the ground that make this easier than I'm imagining. Tell me if I'm wrong! Along these lines, in an intriguing comment below, @Milosz suggests that ISIS in Libya might get into the smuggling game. Quite right, but I suspect it would take them some time to ramp up production (as it were), and that means ISIS (or a similar jihadist group) would be unlikely to have a decisive affect on whether we'll see 1,000,000 seaborne arrivals this year. Four brief points: First, Syria is much closer to Turkey than it is to Egypt, Libya, and Tunisia (which are the major points of embarkation to Italy). Trust me on this, even though I'm an American; I looked this up on a map and everything. Anyway, getting from Syria to Tunisia will take a lot of time, and that means (once again) less relevance for the number of seaborne refugees and migrants in 2016. Second, if I'm reading the data right, at least 96% of the seaborne refugees and migrants who've arrived in Italy this year were themselves African. Nigerians, for instance, have been the most numerous. There just doesn't seem to be a history of Syrians, Iraqis, and Afghans making their way across north Africa in order to make it to Europe, and that means (I think) a lot of informal barriers to travel. (Think of the time you went on vacation where people weren't used to folks from your country - it's much harder and slower to get around.) Third, though arrivals in Italy were 4 times higher in March 2016 than in March 2015, the pace has slowed a lot since then. There were more than 16,000 arrivals in Italy during March 2015, but there have been less than 6,000 halfway through April 2016. So perhaps we're not seeing the uptick that I expected when I thought about a few weeks ago. Fourth, while the overall flow of seaborne refugees and migrants peaked during November of 2015, the peak of the north Africa-Italy route was already falling fast in September of 2015. Let's assume (as seems reasonable) that these ebbs and flows are a result of seasonal weather conditions. If so, we're likely to have a pretty good guess about how many seaborne refugees and migrants will arrive in Europe via this route long before the end of the year[2]. --- [1] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php
[2] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/country.php?id=105

For Pete's sake, I forgot to chance my forecast last time. Justification below.

Europe has already received more than 160,000 refugees this year, about 90.8% of which made landfall in Greece[a]. But, we're told, the migrant flow in Greece has recently fallen from about 1,000/day to about 100/day: "Where thousands arrived in a day, now hundreds — and some days far fewer — splash onto the Greek shores from Turkey, a possible sign that the largest mass migration of the 21st century is slowing or that refugees are changing course as Europe scrambles to erect new barriers"[b]. Let's assume that the fall in the number of arrivals is really a result of political changes and not just changes in the weather or in other conditions that would cause a sharp but temporary lessening of the flow of refugees and migrants. How should we extrapolate this change over the rest of 2016?  One answer is that we should expect current conditions to continue more-or-less as they are. So by December 31, the total number of refugees and migrants who have arrived in Europe will be 160,000 (i.e., the number who are already there) + 27,700 (100 refugees per day for the next 277 days arriving in Greece) + 48,000 (the remaining 9.2% of refugees who arrive by sea elsewhere than in Greece and who - I think - won't be deterred by the EU's deal with Turkey). So the answer is that we should expect about 235,700 by the end of 2016. But what are the assumptions behind this model, and how reasonable are they? Well, the number of refugees in 2015 varied greatly by month, and October saw more than 40 times as many refugees and migrants as January. So perhaps it's more reasonable to project a 90% reduction in refugees and migrants over the year, rather than a constant flow of 100/day. Using last year as a baseline, that would mean 90,000 more refugees and migrants in Greece, not 27,700. But that's still a lot less than 1,000,000. In fact, if we leave aside (for the moment) the question of refugees and migrants arriving elsewhere than in Greece, the EU would only have to impose a 25-or-so% reduction on 2015 on the flow of refugees and migrants in order to keep the total number under 1 million. That seems achievable, though that fact has to be counterbalanced with the fact that the flow of refugees and migrants is 7 times higher during the first 3 months of 2016 than it was during the same months in 2015.   Perhaps this way of thinking of it helps: The demand curve for refugee/migrant status in the EU has been moving sharply out and to the right when compared to 2014 and even 2015 (though its has been slowing steadily since November). Up to this point, the supply curve for refugee/migrant status in the EU has been pretty flat. The result is just what you'd expect: the quantity of refugees/migrants in the EU has gone up dramatically when compared to previous years. But the EU is now trying to cut the quantity supplied by indirectly raising the price of admission. (Obviously, the EU can't directly raise the price, though it is a monopolist of sorts, because the price is paid, not to the EU, but to people who facilitate their travel[c].) So while the demand curve is moving out and to the right, the supply curve is shifting on its axis to be less horizontal and more vertical, i.e., it is experiencing greater price inelasticity of supply [d]. Under these conditions, one can't say what will happen to the equilibrium quantity of refugees/migrants in the EU, unless one knows more about the relative shapes, positions, and movements of both the supply and demand curves. And I doubt anyone has anything more than a crude guess about any of that. Well, I sure don't. But when the demand curve moves out and to the right while the supply curve become for inelastic, you can be damn sure that the price will go up. How much are people willing and able to pay to get the European shores (that is, what's the price inelasticity of demand, as opposed to supply)? That's really the big question, as I see it. If demand is highly inelastic, then, in the long run, refugees and migrants who are trying to get to the EU will just consume other, more expensive, ways of getting there (other than, e.g., the fairly cheap trip from western Turkey to one of the nearby Greek islands, like Lesvos).  Are refugees and migrants willing and able to pay enough to land in Italy including Sicily (please forgive me, my Sicilian friends) as they already have this year to the tune of almost 5,000/month? The trip from Libya to Italy runs $500-$2,000[e]. That's half as much as people were paying for the land voyage to the EU last year[f], and I'm not even sure that's a real option anymore. If we see a sharp rise in the amount of money that refugees and migrants are willing and able to pay during the next, say, five weeks, then I'd expect the chances of getting to 1,000,000 by the end of 2016 are still pretty high. If not, then not. How to find out whether such a sharp rise occurs? I'm working on that.... -- [a] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php [b] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/eu-deal-to-stop-migrants-puts-fear-in-those-waiting-in-turkey/2016/03/26/77c2cc3e-f114-11e5-a2a3-d4e9697917d1_story.html [c] http://www.ibtimes.com/syrian-refugees-heading-europe-are-big-business-lebanons-travel-agents-2126557 [d] http://www.economicsonline.co.uk/Competitive_markets/Price_elasticity_of_supply.html [e] http://www.altaiconsulting.com/mixedmigrationlibya/Altai_Consulting-UNHCR-Mixed_Migration_Libya.pdf [f] http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/refugee-smuggling-a-big-business-in-the-balkans-a-1051461.html

The advisor to the United Nations envoy on Syria today reported further progress in the humanitarian relief efforts in that conflict-battered country, including with more areas reached, medical kits getting through checkpoints, and children being vaccinated.
Briefing the media in Geneva, Jan Egeland, the Special Advisor to UN Special Envoy for Syria Staffan de Mistura, said that humanitarian convoys have already reached or got verbal Government consent to reach most of the 18 besieged areas, except Darayya and Douma. Last night, an inter-agency convoy of UN, International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), and Syrian Arab Red Crescent arrived in Al Houla in Homs, for the first time since last October, he said. Also, a convoy reached the Orem area in western Aleppo over the weekend. "We are now up to 384,000 people reached since the beginning of the year via inter-agency convoys in hard-to-reach areas, besieged areas, and other priority cross-line areas," he said.
With verbal permissions having just been issued for eight or nine of the 11 areas UN requested for April, that number is expected to double in the coming weeks, he added. He also reported that medical kits went through to Al Houla after extensive negotiations. But surgical material was again taken off the convoys. "It is a war zone; civilians and others need surgical help," he said.
Turning to the vaccination campaign, he said vaccinating children is symbolically important in a conflict, and especially in a peace effort. "There is nothing more symbolic than children being able to resume school and being vaccinated against diseases," he said, noting that one million children in hard-to-reach and besieged areas will be vaccinated by the end of April through the facilitation of the UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the World Health Organization (WHO).
Air drops are expected to start in "days and weeks" over Deir ez-Zor, where 200,000 civilians, mostly women and children, are waiting for relief aid, he said. Meanwhile, the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) reported today that it has continued humanitarian operations in Yalda for the sixth consecutive week. A medical team comprised of two medical officers, two nurses and one assistant pharmacist was deployed for the fourth time since February, when the UN agency was allowed to resume operations to support vulnerable civilians from Yarmouk, Yalda, Babila and Beit Saham. The medical team reportedly treated 253 patients today, including 114 women and 78 children, for a range of non-communicable and other common diseases.

The EU TURKEY - deal? The EU reluctantly coming to the table with Turkey to stem the refugee waves seems to have yielded some results after tough negotiations: It now has the right to send the refugees back to Turkey and also has been promised an increase in border security measures by Turkey.In turn, Turkey has been promised 6 billion euros (roughly $6.8 billion) of financial aid for the refugees in the country, visa exemptions for Turks after a set of criteria are fulfilled and the launch of a new chapter to reanimate the EU membership process.
Turkey has until April to comply with 72 different criteria in order to obtain the visa exemption for the European Union.
"There is also a stipulation on establishing an independent commission on monitoring human rights violations by the security forces. There are many criteria. Turkey will be labeled a democratic country if it can implement all of them. Europe for the time being seems to go along with the negotiations, although it knows that these criteria will not be met.”
He added, “The implementation process will be evaluated after the agreement is signed and it will become clear in June 2016 that it will not happen."
Meanwhile, objections are already being heard from Europe. Frans Timmermans, the vice president of the European Commission, said that the visa exemption for Turkey depends on the requirements and that there is no "shortcut" for this. Timmermans, noting that the visa exemption will not be easy to accomplish, also said the requirements must be met by April.
The negotiation of the readmission agreement, which is jointly discussed with Turkey’s visa exemption for the EU, is not a new idea. Turkey, upon signing the agreement, promises to take back the refugees who originated from the east of Turkey and migrated to Europe. However, experts again warn there might be legal disputes with this agreement. Turkey being a signatory of the 1957 Geneva Convention and the added protocol of 1967 does not recognize asylum seekers as refugees. The refugees in the country are only accepted as “guests.” Here we can talk about an extended protection exclusive to the Syrian refugees but no one has full refugee status. This may lead to a debate on Turkey not meeting the directives of the European Parliament on readmission of refugees in a “safe third country.” According to EU law expert Steve Peers of the University of Essex and Emanuela Roman, a visiting researcher at Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam, Turkey fails to meet the requirements of being a “safe third country" because it does not recognize the refugee status, not to mention the increasing claims of torture and maltreatment of refugees. Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International have published reports on maltreatment of refugees in Turkey. As a result, it is held that according to European legislation, the refugees cannot be readmitted to Turkey. While Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said Turkey must show progress on freedom of speech and media, Cyprus has clearly declared that it would veto Turkey’s EU membership. Declarations from France, Cyprus and Italy indicate that even if new chapters are initiated for Turkey's EU membership process, they will not be finalized.

The recent deal between the EU and Turkey[a] is probably behind the recent drop in the GJ consensus on this question[b]. But I doubt that's the entire story. There's also been a fall off in the number of migrants and refugees since January[c]. The numbers really tell two difficult-to-reconcile tales. On the one had, the decline from January to February and from February to March suggests that we're riding a function that will get asymptotically close to zero as the summer months approach. If that happens, then - of course - there won't be anything close to 1 million refugees and migrants entering Europe this year. On the other hand, two factors push toward the opposite conclusion. First, the number of refugees and migrants tends to increase sharply as we get closer to the second half of the year because of the better weather. Second, there have already been more than 161,000 refugees and migrants in 2016, 8 times as many as the 22,000 at the end of March in 2015[d]. So now what? I suppose one could use a simple function to describe last year's flow of refugees and migrants and then develop another function from this year's flow up to this point in order to extrapolate the flow for the remainder of the year, and, finally, average the two functions. That would be a nice way to kill a little time.  But it might be more fruitful to think about the causal factors in play. bout half (44%) of the refugees and migrants are Syrian, and it's no secret why so many of these good folks want to leave their homeland, at least for now. If conditions stabilize in Syria, the rate of flow will decrease or at least stabilize at a lower level; if not, then not. Russia's unexpectedly swift withdrawal does not, in and of itself, resolve this matter. Assad is in much better shape now than he was six months ago[e]. But that doesn't mean the civil war is over. It's probably closer to the truth to say that Syria has returned to the status quo from a few years ago: a stalemate between Assad and his enemies[f]. Will the parties to the conflict recognize this situation and deescalate? Maybe[g]. And maybe not[h]. I think it's way too soon to tell, and I doubt I can do better than to assign a 0.50 probability to each outcome for now. If nothing else, that means the expected number of refugees and migrants should decrease, since I was operating under the assumption of continued bloody civil war. That said, only half of the refugees and migrants are coming from Syria. There are enough coming from Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran, and Iraq to push the number of refugees and migrants quite high. The other major causal factor in play at the moment is Europe's (let me be frank) clumsy and embarrassing attempt to get Turkey to staunch the flow of refugees and migrants. It hasn't been going well so far: "Thousands of Afghans and Iraqis may escape deportation to Turkey as the EU's €6 billion (£4.7 billion) deal descended into chaos. In a major blow for Brussels, Turkish government sources said they would not change their domestic law to grant Afghans and Iraqis refugee status in Turkey, and to prevent them being deported to warzones. The EU says those changes are essential to make the deal compliant with international law, and therefore to commence deportations"[i]. Read the whole thing, but only if you've got a strong stomach. Anyway, it's not even clear that the efforts to stop the flow of refugees and migrants is likely to have much of an affect even if interdiction were carried out with considerably less pandaemonium. Problems with sea-worthy vessels appears to be a larger deterrent than the antics of the Keystone Cops a la Turk[j]. But the take away from the point of view of forecasting this question (for me, at any rate) is that some effort to interdict refugees and migrants is being made. My earlier forecast operated on the (then valid) assumption that no such thing was going on. And there's at least some chance that this farrago of willful myopia, selfishness, moral cowardice, and brutality will keep some desperate people from landing on the shores of Lesvos.  <<getting off my soapbox now>> On the basis of all of this, I'm adjusting the probability that there will be 1 million or more new refugees and migrants in Europe this year from 68% to 59%, with more downward revisions in sight if Syria continues to stabilize and EU can manage to wash its hands of the kinds of people who were some common in Europe just a few decades ago.  -- [a] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35854413 [b] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/106-will-more-than-1-million-refugees-and-migrants-arrive-in-europe-by-sea-in-2016 [c] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php [d] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php [e] http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/03/putin-russia-withdrawal-syria-assad-turkey.html# [f] http://www.vox.com/2016/3/15/11240318/putin-syria-withdrawal-retro [g] http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/03/13/world/middleeast/syria-control-isis-maps-cease-fire-civil-war-five-years.html [h] http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/syria-war-five-years-hunger-horror-heartbreak-n538661 [i] http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/12200270/Chaos-surrounds-EU-Turkey-deal-as-migrants-keep-flowing-into-Greece.html [j] http://www.dailysabah.com/nation/2016/03/21/boat-problems-not-turkey-eu-deal-deter-migrants-heading-to-europe

Going a little higher than the crowd, for a few reasons (all articulated by top forecasters before me): 1. The IMF's prediction was apparently "3 million" in mid-January. I don't trust the IMF that far, but I do somewhat trust them not to be off by a factor of 3. 2. "The EU takes decisive action to stem the tides of social change" = headline I don't expect to see this year (or next). 3. Migration accelerated very, very quickly in 2015 because people were being slaughtered or mired in hopeless poverty if they did not migrate. To decelerate migration this year as quickly as it accelerated last year, perhaps we'd need some equally dramatic factor in the other direction? (This proposal resonates emotionally with me, but not logically; I'm giving it very low weight.) There are powerful factors against the 2015 record being broken -- lots of national-level policy changes, for one -- but it seems natural to me that migrants would care much more about the place they were leaving than the place they are going. Does someone moving from Eritrea carefully weigh the chances of being stuck in Turkey vs. making it to France? (They probably do, but not as carefully as the average GJOpen member -- they don't have the same level of access to data, for example, though they do get to see changing prices, so... this is a close call.) COMMENT:
FACTORS SUPPORTING 1M +
-counts for Jan & Feb this year are more than 10 times higher than for Jan & Feb last year
-military campaigns against major cities (Aleppo & Mosul) are expected this year, causing major population displacement
-EU can't get its act together to stop the flow
-Greece's islands create a porous border.  It would take a gigantic naval policing effort to stop the flow.
-it's still winter:  bad weather is impeding the flow.  Numbers have always been higher in the summer months.
-the immigration machine has become well-oiled
-the solution to saturation in northern EU countries may be major camps in Greece (since Turkey is an unreliable partner) FACTORS SUPPORTING UNDER 1M

Here are a few general points that helped me understand the context: The BBC reports that "More than a million migrants and refugees crossed into Europe in 2015." Specially 1,294,000, 78% (just over 1 million) of whom arrive by sea, and 37% of whom seek asylum in Germany. The most common entry points are in the Mediterranean: Spain, Italy, and - especially - Greece [1]. Currently, Syrians make up about half of the migrants and refugees crossing into Europe, though about a quarter come from Afghanistan. Importantly, only 283,532 migrants and refugees entered Europe in 2014[2]. So 2015 represents a roughly 450% increase in the number of migrants and refugees entering Europe. Over the long run, I expect the number of sea-borne migrants and refugees entering Europe (hereafter "M&Rs" - note that I'll take the qualification "by sea" for granted and not repeat it in order to avoid some tedium) to return to previous historical levels. But the current situation in many way does not resemble the historical situation. Trying to estimate the number of men 18-30 who would die in Europe is usually best done by looking at earlier historical levels. But from 1939-1945, the previous historical levels would have been pretty useless. I think we're in a situation more-or-less like that with regard to M&Rs in Europe.  There often seem to be two sides to the equation. One is a demand side; here, M&Rs seeking entry to Europe. The other is a supply side; the EU and individual European nation-states (including non-EU nation-states like Switzerland) who can grant entry to Europe. The demand side of the equation looks to remain very high. To engage in a bit of reckless generalization, the situation in places like Syria and Afghanistan (which made up about 70% of M&Rs in 2015) does not appear to be getting any better. Similarly, places like Iraq and Iran continue to generate sizable numbers of M&Rs. None of these countries appear to have been emptied of potential M&Rs either. So on the demand side, last year is probably the best guide for this year. Since the number of M&Rs in 2015 was a bit over 1 million, I'd bet that there is a high probability (70% or so) that the number will be between 850,000 and 1,250,000 for 2016, with smallish tails (15% or so) on both sides. That translates to about a 52% chance that over 1 million M&Rs. Obliviously, I'll want to continue to update the demand numbers as more information becomes available. And the UNHCR reports that there have been 130,110 (call it 130,000) M&Rs so far (2/29) in 2016. That's about 13% of 1,000,000 M&Rs, about 16% of the way through the year. So it looks as if we're a bit off the pace of 2015. But in fact the number of R&Ms went up considerably in later months of 2015, peaking in October. If I'm reading the data right, there were only 5,550M&Rs in January 2015 and 7,271 M&Rs in February 2015[3]. So, if I'm reading the situation rightly (and I really wonder if I am since the result is so surprising), we're an order of magnitude ahead of the pace set in 2015. Another way to put it is this: At the end of February, 2015 the total number of M&Rs was 1% of 1,000,000. At the end of February, 2016 the total number of M&Rs was 13% of 1,000,000. All of this suggests that the probability that demand side will be over a million is higher than 52%. I'd call it something closer to 75%, with that probability rising if the number of M&Rs remains so high in March.  But what about the supply side? The EU and individual European nation-states could limit the number of places for M&Rs. Austria[4], Hungary[5], and Slovenia[6] have done so, as have some other European nation-states. But these are largely barriers to entry (or migration internal to Europe) by land. These barriers will not (directly) prevent entry by sea. There has been some talk of the EU "ring-fencing" Greece[7], which would probably make an already difficult situation in that troubled country much worse. But Greece is still a part of the EU, so a landing there is still a landing in Europe, which is all that matters for the purposes of this question. Perhaps some think that ring-fencing Greece would force the Greek government to discourage M&Rs further. However, I doubt Greece has the resources necessary to do much more than they already are. (BTW, the human cost to the M&Rs of being subjected to - what to say? - a low cost effort to prevent landing in the EU would likely be horrendous[8].) In general, the EU has just not (yet) shown that it can change much on the supply side of the equation, though that might change. So a 75% likelihood that there will be 1,000,000 or more M&Rs in 2016 looks right to me for now. --- [1] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34131911 [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_migrant_crisis [3] http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php [4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austrian_border_barrier [5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_border_barrier [6] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovenian_border_barrier [7] http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c40504cc-c12b-11e5-9fdb-87b8d15baec2.html#axzz41an3ZbDM [8] http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/22/could-australia-stop-the-boats-policy-solve-europe-migrant-crisis

Following my previous forecast (1), I realize that I hadn't considered that an increase in refugees over summer may be a yearly thing. We are begged the question: How likely is it that we are going to see a summer surge of a similar size as 2015? Or, alternatively, to what extent was the 2015 surge caused by predictable climatic patterns? I will argue that climate did not play the dominant role in the 2015 crisis.  - If we look at the 2014 data (2), we indeed see a summer surge - however, unlike 2015, the 2014 surge started around April, peaked in August - September and died down around October-November. Furthermore, it is not clear that a huge summer surge happens most years. The best data I could find from a google search (3) shows that sea arrivals *don't* follow a clear pattern: In 2012, Sea arrivals were highest in Q4; in 2011, they were highest in Q2, but Q1 was very close and Q3 was much further below (If anyone finds some nice data for 2013, please let me know). - We *can* say for certain that a surge of a magnitude of 2015 - where October rates were roughly 20x higher than they were in march - is totally unprecedented (in recent years). Squinting at the graph tells me that in the peak of the 2014 surge, the rate was about 4x higher than march. So unless the weather in the Mediterranean was *unbelievably* conducive to immigration that summer, I'm fairly certain that the surge was rooted in politics. - The rate of arrivals by sea is decreasing much, much faster than you would expect to be caused by climate. December 2015 had nearly twice as many arrivals as January 2016, but it'd be pretty absurd to believe that migrating during January is twice as difficult as migrating during December. Similarly, February will probably see less than 30,000 arrivals, which is less than half of January, which really can't be caused by climate. This suggests that the late 2015 surge is still in the process of dying, and we should expect a much more routine year in 2016. So: Assuming we see 100,000 arrivals this Jan and Feb (I think this is a bit generous, but nonetheless), we'd need another 900,000 arrivals over the course of the year (90,000 per month). The peak of the 2014 surge had about 40,000 per month. The only way that we'll see more than a million arrivals this year is if there's a repeat of the (almost certainly politically caused) surge of 2015, and I'm not sure why we should expect that. I did bump the chance up from 7% to 9%, but I still think it's really unlikely. I'll update depending on the intake for Feb and March. I'm expecting about 30,000 arrivals in February - if it's more than that i'll bump up, if it's less I'll bump down. I'm pretty sure this is one of the questions where the rest of GJP is just *wrong*. There is a definite downwards trend in the number of refugees arriving by sea (1). The peak was in October, when 221k people arrived, and it's fallen dramatically since then - 65k people arrived this January, and only 14k arrived between 1-11 Feb. If we assume the rate of arrival this February to remain constant then only 30k will arrive this month. If we predict another 30k for the remaining months of the year, then there are only going to be 400,000 arrivals in 2016, which is less than half of the required number. There are 2 ways that I think the current rate will more than double: 
- Europe massively eases its immigration restrictions. This seems incredibly unlikely, as the political climate has become increasingly opposed to immigration - it would be political suicide in most European countries to suggest that they take more immigrants in right now. I'd say there's at most a 3% chance of this happening. - A major war breaks out in North Africa or the Middle East, leading to an extra 600,000 more immigrants arriving. This is also pretty unlikely: Sure, wars break out all the time but very rarely do they involve 600,000 refugees in less than a year. Given that 41% of arrivals are from Syria, we'd expect 164,000 Syrians to arrive this year - meaning that for a war (or number of wars) to produce 600,000 refugees this year, it would have to be more than three times as violent as the Syrian war (or even larger if it happened later in the year). This is... unlikely. I'll call it 2%. Random fluctuations do not seem like a plausible way for refugee intake to increase this much, but I'll be a little cautious and put it at 1%. 1 - (0.99 *0.98 *0.97) = 6%.  (1) http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php

In this forecast I hope to challenge my forecasting colleagues to: 1) re-evaluate the predictive value of some of the observables they are reporting upon, and 2) become familiar with a particular concept that may re-direct, or at least expand, the scope of search for appropriate observables. 1) If we consider the EU as an isolated system, the question asks us to quantify the number of refuges that enter that system via the sea. Movements of refugees between countries are movements within the system, not movements *into* the system. It's not that internal flow information on refugees is not relevant at all, but only that it might be less relevant to the question than we might initially assume. The internal migration chain might "back up" to the EU frontier. The methods of handling internal border movements might be indicative of attitudes of decision makers, etc. But I'm suggesting we need to focus more on identifying the causal factors relating to the ultimate source of refugees (even the specific battles maybe) and the nature of the EU system interface that adjoins the seas.
2) I call your attention again, to the paper by Kelly Greenhill, entitled "Weapons of Mass Migration" (provided to us courtesy of @praedico, and which I promise I will not reference again): http://calhoun.nps.edu/bitstream/handle/10945/11515/SI_V9_I1_2010_Greenhill_116.pdf I suggest, also for the last time, that we are seeing the theories espoused in this paper played out before us in real time. My essential claim is that, if this is true, we are witnessing a covert coercive bargaining game of sorts. Or, at least this is one possibility that we should not neglect to seek evidence for or against. I call your attention also to the following article which while headlined under, and beginning with, an orientation toward tensions relating to internal open borders, moves on to address the issue of Turkey as a "valve" of sorts capable of determining the absolute volume of the flow. I could not find the reference from the recent IMF report that stated Europe is to expect 3 million refugees in 2016. This number was referenced by another commenter. It could be that we are looking at different reports or I missed it. Alternatively, it could be an error by the other commenter. 
Here is the report I reviewed: http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/sdn/2016/sdn1602.pdfThis report states: “Based on an inflow of 1.3 million first-time asylum seekers annually from 2015–17, tapering off afterwards, coupled with a 40 percent rejection rate.”(pg.13) If these asylum seekers are mostly sea arrivals, then the IMF believes that at least one million refugees will arrive by sea  in 2016. Unfortunately, the report does not explain how they arrived at this estimate.  My outside view at this point breaks down as follows:
Refugee inflows by sea (2016): 
<500K (5%) (almost certainly not) 
501K – 750K (30%) (probably not)
751K – 1.2 mil. (65%) (Probable) Inside View Factors (weights are percentages that would be applied to current expected outcome): 1.	Weather. Although it would seem like an important variable, the desire to enter Europe seems to outweigh the challenges of the sea in the worst months. No weight to this variable. 
2.	Turkey taking steps to better accommodate/integrate refugees. Although the EU has pledged Turkey 3 billion to help manage the crisis and stem the flow, it remains to be seen if the deal holds and what Turkey does with the money.  I am dubious about the prospect of spending one’s way out of this crisis. For these reasons, I am not giving this variable much weight. (-1)
3.	Border controls. If the refugee flows continue unabated, the passport-free Schengen Area is in real danger of collapsing. If this happens, the flow could be stemmed as word spreads in the refugee producing countries that the path through Europe is closed. If this does happen, then I would estimate this would have a significant impact on sea arrivals. This could swing percentages considerably. (-15-20)
4.	European social unrest. The recent events in Cologne, Germany and the rise of the right in Europe do not bode well for sentiments toward refugees. If these tensions escalate to violence in Europe, pressure could be applied to close borders or impose stricter limits on inflows. From the refugee side, social unrest in Europe might seem benign compared to what they are leaving. So, the rise in anti-refugee sentiment might not dissuade people from making the trip to Europe. (-4)
5.	Improvements in the conditions of the countries producing the most refugees. If you look at the top four: Syria, Afghanistan, Iraq, Eritrea, no current news suggests any improvement in conditions in the short term. Eritrea is the only one where things may get better. The others are failed states and war zones. No weight to this variable.  Since my “probable” range includes an outcome where the question would not resolve in my favor, I am stating at the outset that I believe the likelihood is at least 1 mil. or more. I’ll make adjustments accordingly.

Current European policy settings are not effective at preventing or deterring migrants from attempting to enter Europe. While there are signs of hardening rhetoric in Germany, whose policies (and whose Chancellor's statements) have served as the biggest magnet, rhetoric alone will not stop people coming. There is a big gap between tough talk and actively closing the doors - and the lure of a better life is stronger than any deterrents on the horizon. It is also worth bearing in mind that migration often has a lag time, with individuals needing to make arrangements, sell their possessions, arrange passage with smugglers and undertake the journey. Moreover, many of those who have successfully made the journey in 2015 will act as anchors and will project confidence to friends and family members in their communities back home, encouraging these people will seek to emulate that journey. So long as the passage from Turkey to Greece and from North Africa to Italy remains effectively open, the numbers attempting the journey are likely to be even higher in 2016 than in 2015. Even in the unlikely event of an effective ceasefire occurring in Syria in 2016 (which I assess at an approximately 10% chance), migrants from a number of other source countries/regions, not least West Africa, are still likely to make the journey, if primarily for (perfectly understandable) economic and lifestyle reasons. The rise of anti-migration and right-wing parties offers some risk to this prediction but not in the short term and only in respect of some countries, not to the point of preventing migration to Europe as a whole.

It's worth looking at the numbers [1]. Around 50% of the total refugee count in 2015 was due to Syria. Even after last year, there are more than 2 million refugees lined up in Turkey. A significant portion of those will wind up attempting to get to Europe. Whether we hit 1 million this year depends on the following:
- Whether the Syrian civil war continues (likely)
- Whether further refugees are displaced
- The treatment of those refugees in neighboring countries (i.e. how likely to flee elsewhere)
- The extent to which Turkey tries to prevent further flight to Europe
- The extent to which refugees perceive Europe as being a better option (likely, particularly since EU is slowly recovering economically, and Turkey is currently struggling)  I'm going to start at 90%, and will adjust if necessary. There's a lot of opportunity for wildcards here... [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War

Following the comments and analysis of @AndrewSabisky, in particular. The UNHCR input is particularly helpful. The EU is unlikely to make any attempts to seriously protect its borders in the short term, regardless of public discontent in numerous countries at the level of migration (of whom actual refugees in practice only appear to constitute a small proportion). Thus far the principal attempts to deal with the crisis have been to impose checks on national borders within the EU (Sweden-Denmark, Denmark-Germany, France-Italy), rather to seriously check external borders. As yet the political - not to mention institutional - will to do so appears limited: and the EU bureaucracy has shown itself to be anything but fast-moving (indeed, decision-making structures prevent it from so being). The ECHR will impede deportations of those who arrive illegally (a few smaller EU countries - perhaps Poland, Hungary, conceivably Czech Republic) might ignore this - but such countries are hardly the principal intended destinations of migrants. Should more nationalist governments come to power in major EU states, the situation could change - but even in such cases national governments would still have great fights with the EU institutions over numerous areas of sovereignty. Meanwhile the conflict in Syria continues without end in sight, and the increasingly hot-headed authorities in Saudi Arabia behave increasingly aggressively in exacerbating the conflict in several of its neighbours, while the situation in Libya is not, at least, overtly, stabilising or improving, while that in Afghanistan appears to be set on deteriorating. While the number of people beyond the Mid-East who have both the means and the desire to be smuggled into Europe, with no regard for legality, is also not deteriorating,

Current demographic expansion in the Middle East and North Africa area will be exceeded by the Southern African and West African regions. The later regions will continue to destabilize from conflict and/or disease outbreaks and economic deprivations. The movement of peoples from the Southern and West African regions is drawn geographically northward into MENA and is exacerbated by continual propaganda saying generous welfare, jobs, and living conditions are available Europe. The result is general and continual displacement of populations in MENA. Meanwhile, the Middle East will continue to see expansion of violence if not general warfare.  Simultaneously, a various political agencies are stating that the release of these tensions in the Middle East can be found by moving people into Europe. Furthermore, the general leftist and globalist orientation of the European ruling parties and classes makes it contingent upon them to prove not only their ideological support for bringing in all of the aforementioned displaced populations but to improve their class wealth by bringing in larger numbers of cheap labor. Equally important, bringing in such large numbers of large alien populations helps dilute not only working and middle class communities, but above all the national cohesion of the nation-states in the EU. As the later represents an obstacle to seamless borders, interchangeable socio-economic sectors, and centralization of power in the EU, their dilution with foreign nationalities helps sustain and increase the power of the European "project." Finally, there is little national leaders can do to protect European borders short of direct military intervention toward border defense. The result, will be greater than 1,000,000 refugees, asylees, and immigrants entering the EU in 2016.

Ok, I just got off the phone to UNCHR Greece. I rang to ask them what their predictions were for 2016. The response seemed to be that "we'll, we're not making a prediction, but we are planning for at least as many people as 2015, and maybe a bit more". That biases me towards upwards of 50% on this IFP. (I have also emailed UNCHR headquarters and will let you guys know when/if I get a response) Further thoughts: 1:) eyeballing the 2015 data at http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php, it's obvious that despite all the hype, the death rates on the sea journey are very low - under half a percent. Given the potential economic payoffs of a likely journey to Europe, such a death rate is unlikely to deter anyone. Deaths at sea this winter appear to have been quite low, evidence of both good weather and perhaps also that the smuggling operations have got more professional (any data on this?) 2:) the Syrian conflict appears frozen and is unlikely to resolve in any kind of way any time soon.  3): migrant flow is not purely a function of violence in Syria. Only 49% of migrants making the sea journey in 2015 actually came from Syria (http://data.unhcr.org/mediterranean/regional.php), and given the prevalance of fake Syrian passports this number is likely to be a substantial overestimate. Much of the third world has become just rich enough for substantial numbers of its people to be able to afford the journey to a Europe which thus far has proved totally unwilling to defend its borders, creating a substantial pull factor in addition to the push. 4:) while Europe can arguably shut down land-based migration through Bulgaria very easily if it wants, this will just push migrants onto the sea route 5:) The European Court of Human Rights takes the view that sending migrants back once they have reached European territory is practically illegal (see p.20) http://www.coe.int/t/democracy/migration/Source/migration/ProtectingMigrantsECHR_ESCWeb.pdf. This severely limits the options Europe has to cut the pull factor. 6:) therefore, it is not immediately obvious to me what Europe can really do to shut sea-route migrant flow down without taking the drastic step of ignoring the ECHR, even if more terrorist attacks and incidents like the Rape of Cologne (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35231046) occur (as they inevitably will). 7;) betting on quick and efficient EU decision-making and action has historically proved a very stupid thing to do

EDITED to change my OCT deadline for political solution to AUG. Europe in 2016 will be much less welcoming in 2015, but the same can be said about the 2nd half of 2015 as compared to the first half.  Consider the growth rates by month from 2014 to 2015. 1. In January 2015, there were 5,550 comapred to 3,270, a 70% uplift
2. In February 2015, there were 7,231, a 66% uplift
3. In March, 10,424, a 43% uplift.
4. In April, 75%; May 138%, June 108%, July 177%
5. In August, 280%, September 382%,
6. In October 862%, November 1061%, December 1138%
7. First 5 days of January 2016: 11x the daily arrival rate of 2015; 19x the daily arrival rate of 2014 All signs point to an acceleration of sea arrivals in the latter half of 2015 and the beginning of 2016.  To give you a feel, you need an average of 3,000 daily arrivals by sea to get to YES on this.  They are at 2,000 per day in the first 5 days of 2016.  This is in very bad sea conditions and the corresponding figure is <200 in 2015.  The by-land arrivals can be stopped through various means but it is not clear what to do with people on a boat. Another consideration is that the people most desperate to escape have already arrived.  Syria has 22 million people, 500K have gone to europe in 2015, 4 million have gone elsewhere.  Presumably there are 18 million who remain.  But we will see escalation of civil war in both Syria and Iraq (100K in 2015) and some of the 4 million may be tempted to take the boat trip as the technology of the journey improves.  I dont see the 'supply' of refugees as a factor here and it may actually increase as smugglers attract capital and increase efficiency.  Absent a change in European policy (which is to welcome anyone who arrives on a boat) I put this at 80% odds of exceeding 1 million. (20% odds) Policy response 1: The Australian policy of a naval blockade so that no boats can arrive, this leads to a definite NO response if it is implemented before October 1 and reverts to my 80% chance if not. (10% odds) Policy response 2: Safe haven in Syria. Steer refugees to a cheap and safe camp with UN boots on the ground in Syria. (5% odds) Political solution: Assad is killed and ISIS is routed with some kind of caretaker pluralistic government.  NO if this starts to happen by Oct 1. (5% odds) Air or land bridge.  Some kind of yellow brick road or free flights to Europe are set up. NO if this doesnt appear imminent by Oct 1. (60% odds) Status Quo: 80% My calculation on Jan 5 says that 60%*80 + 45%*33%*80% = 60%.  This number will increase each day with no political attempt to solve the problem.
I"m going no because I think Syria will come to a close soon. As soon as ISIS is beaten Russia, Iran and the U.S. will broker a deal for elections instead of insisting Assad to step down.
